Dear Dog Owners,
My name is Lily Paxton, and I'm the town's Pet Program Coordinator. As part of our goal to make the community more dog-friendly, we recently opened a new dog park. The park was designed to provide an enjoyable experience for both dogs and owners. There are big grassy areas where your dogs can run, jump, and play. We have separate spaces for small dogs and big dogs, to ensure safety. You'll also find lots of benches and areas for resting and staying cool. We hope you will have a wonderful time with your dogs in this newly opened park.
Regards, Lily Paxton, Pet Program Coordinator

Maya waited in line to check in for her flight. Her expectations about her European backpacking trip were really high. She had been looking forward to the trip for a year. She couldn't wait to visit museums in Madrid and see the Eiffel Tower at night in Paris. As she stood in line, she could feel those experiences were finally so close. When she approached the counter, the airline employee asked to see her passport. Maya reached into her pocket but felt nothing. She realized she had left her passport at home. Her plans were ruined. She was heartbroken, knowing she could not board the flight and had to delay her dream trip.

People often ask me, "What surprises you most about habits?" One thing that continually astonishes me is the degree to which we're influenced by sheer convenience. The amount of effort, time, or decision making required by an action has a huge influence on habit formation. To a truly remarkable extent, we're more likely to do something if it's convenient, and less likely if it's not. For this reason, we should pay close attention to the convenience of any activity we want to make into a habit. Putting a wastebasket next to our front door made mail sorting slightly more convenient, and I stopped procrastinating with this chore. Many people report that they do a much better job of staying close to distant family members now that tools like group chats make it easy to stay in touch.

It is common sense that people's inner beliefs may drive their external behavior. If you're attracted to a certain person, you should be more likely to socialize with that person. If you favor a brand of toothpaste, you're more likely to buy it. Of course, our internal thoughts don't always predict our public behavior, but, overall, what we do obviously reflects what we think. But beliefs and behaviors are also related in a more remarkable way. It turns out that the arrow is as likely to point in the reverse direction. As social psychologist David Myers observes, "If social psychology has taught us anything during the last 25 years, it is that we are likely not only to think ourselves into a way of acting but also to act ourselves into a way of thinking."

Imagine following the spirit of a silence vow into daily life. Challenge yourself to spend an entire day saying only what you absolutely must say. It's been widely observed by behavioral psychology experts —  and anyone who's ever been on a first date —  that we too often tend to treat "conversation" as a game of waiting for our own turn to speak. We miss what's being said because we're mentally rehearsing our next utterance. What if you could eliminate the idea that the next available mini-silence is your next opening to express whatever is in your head? What if you were limited to, say, fifty spoken words tomorrow? I think you'd listen quite differently. You'd attend quite carefully to every word you heard. You'd be attuned to what you must respond to. You might discover that the less you say, the more you hear.

Science is concerned with accumulating and understanding observations of the physical world. That understanding alone solves no problems. Individual people have to act on that understanding for it to help solve problems. For instance, science has found that regular exercise can lower your risk of heart disease. Knowing this fact is interesting, but it will do nothing for your personal health unless you act on it and actually exercise. And that's the hard part. Reading an article about exercise is easy. Getting into an actual routine of regular exercise is harder. In this sense, science really solves no problems at all. Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it. In fact, many of humanity's biggest problems are caused by lack of action, and not lack of knowledge.

We think we're being logical, objective, and rational — and therefore accurate in our analysis, judgment, and decisions. So we think that if other people are logical, objective, and rational, they will agree with us and see what we see. But the opposite is the case. Every human brain is different. Everyone's life experience is different. Everyone's desires and knowledge are different. You might think you're being realistic — that is, that your ideas match reality, but that's impossible. It's only your interpretation of reality, which will always be different from someone else's. When two nations play each other in the World Cup, the fans of each country criticize the referees for missing all the infractions that the other team commits. Without fail, each fan base believes that the referees are biased against their team.

Knowing this fact is interesting, but it will do nothing for your personal health unless you act on it and actually exercise. And that's the hard part. Reading an article about exercise is easy. Getting into an actual routine of regular exercise is harder. In this sense, <u>science really solves no problems at all</u>. Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it. In fact, many of humanity's biggest problems are caused by lack of action, and not lack of knowledge.

We think we're being logical, objective, and rational — and therefore accurate in our analysis, judgment, and decisions. So we think that if other people are logical, objective, and rational, they will agree with us and see what we see. But the opposite is the case. Every human brain is different. <u>Everyone's life experience is different</u>. Everyone's desires and knowledge are different. You might think you're being realistic — that is, that your ideas match reality, but that's impossible. It's only your interpretation of reality, which will always be different from someone else's. When two nations play each other in the World Cup, the fans of each country criticize the referees for missing all the infractions that the other team commits. Without fail, each fan base believes that the referees are biased against their team.

People often ask me, "What surprises you most about habits?" One thing that continually astonishes me is the degree to which we're influenced by sheer convenience. The amount of effort, time, or decision making required by an action has a huge influence on habit formation. To a truly remarkable extent, we're more likely to do something if it's convenient, and less likely if it's not. For this reason, we should pay close attention to the convenience of any activity we want to make into a habit. Putting a wastebasket next to our front door made mail sorting slightly more convenient, and I stopped procrastinating with this chore. Many people report that they do a much better job of staying close to distant family members now that tools like group chats make it easy to stay in touch.

It is common sense that people's inner beliefs may drive their external behavior. If you're attracted to a certain person, you should be more likely to socialize with that person. If you favor a brand of toothpaste, you're more likely to buy it. Of course, our internal thoughts don't always predict our public behavior, but, overall, what we do obviously reflects what we think. But beliefs and behaviors are also related in a more remarkable way. It turns out that the arrow is as likely to point in the reverse direction. As social psychologist David Myers observes, "If social psychology has taught us anything during the last 25 years, it is that we are likely not only to think ourselves into a way of acting but also to act ourselves into a way of thinking."

Imagine following the spirit of a silence vow into daily life. Challenge yourself to spend an entire day saying only what you absolutely must say. It's been widely observed by behavioral psychology experts — and anyone who's ever been on a first date — that we too often tend to treat "conversation" as a game of waiting for our own turn to speak. We miss what's being said because we're mentally rehearsing our next utterance. What if you could eliminate the idea that the next available mini-silence is your next opening to express whatever is in your head? What if you were limited to, say, fifty spoken words tomorrow? I think you'd listen quite differently. You'd attend quite carefully to every word you heard. You'd be attuned to what you must respond to. You might discover that the less you say, the more you hear.

Science is concerned with accumulating and understanding observations of the physical world. That understanding alone solves no problems. Individual people have to act on that understanding for it to help solve problems. For instance, science has found that regular exercise can lower your risk of heart disease. Knowing this fact is interesting, but it will do nothing for your personal health unless you act on it and actually exercise. And that's the hard part. Reading an article about exercise is easy. Getting into an actual routine of regular exercise is harder. In this sense, science really solves no problems at all. Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it. In fact, many of humanity's biggest problems are caused by lack of action, and not lack of knowledge.

① Why humanity's biggest challenges persist despite advances in scientific understanding

④ The gap between scientific research and practical implementation of health-related findings
⑤ The difficulty of establishing healthy exercise routines despite scientific knowledge about their benefits

We think we're being logical, objective, and rational — and therefore accurate in our analysis, judgment, and decisions. So we think that if other people are logical, objective, and rational, they will agree with us and see what we see. But the opposite is the case. Every human brain is different. Everyone's life experience is different. Everyone's desires and knowledge are different. You might think you're being realistic — that is, that your ideas match reality, but that's impossible. It's only your interpretation of reality, which will always be different from someone else's. When two nations play each other in the World Cup, the fans of each country criticize the referees for missing all the infractions that the other team commits. Without fail, each fan base believes that the referees are biased against their team.

① The influence of personal experiences on logical reasoning and decision-making processes
② How sports fans demonstrate irrational behavior when supporting their favorite teams
③ Why logical and rational people often disagree despite using similar reasoning methods
④ The challenges of achieving objectivity in international sporting competitions and referee decisions
⑤ The illusion of objectivity in human perception and interpretation of reality

People often ask me, "What surprises you most about habits?" One thing that continually astonishes me is the degree to which we're influenced by sheer convenience. The amount of effort, time, or decision making required by an action has a huge influence on habit formation. To a truly remarkable extent, we're more likely to do something if it's convenient, and less likely if it's not. For this reason, we should pay close attention to the convenience of any activity we want to make into a habit. Putting a wastebasket next to our front door made mail sorting slightly more convenient, and I stopped procrastinating with this chore. Many people report that they do a much better job of staying close to distant family members now that tools like group chats make it easy to stay in touch.

② Convenience: The Key Driver of Habit Formation

④ How Technology Changes Our Daily Routines

It is common sense that people's inner beliefs may drive their external behavior. If you're attracted to a certain person, you should be more likely to socialize with that person. If you favor a brand of toothpaste, you're more likely to buy it. Of course, our internal thoughts don't always predict our public behavior, but, overall, what we do obviously reflects what we think. But beliefs and behaviors are also related in a more remarkable way. It turns out that the arrow is as likely to point in the reverse direction. As social psychologist David Myers observes, "If social psychology has taught us anything during the last 25 years, it is that we are likely not only to think ourselves into a way of acting but also to act ourselves into a way of thinking."

You might discover that the less you say, the more you hear.

Science is concerned with accumulating and understanding observations of the physical world. That understanding alone solves no problems. Individual people have to act on that understanding for it to help solve problems. For instance, science has found that regular exercise can lower your risk of heart disease. Knowing this fact is interesting, but it will do nothing for your personal health unless you act on it and actually exercise. And that's the hard part. Reading an article about exercise is easy. Getting into an actual routine of regular exercise is harder. In this sense, science really solves no problems at all. Problems are only solved when people take the __________ provided by science and use it. In fact, many of humanity's biggest problems are caused by lack of action, and not lack of knowledge.

My name is Lily Paxton, and I'm the town's Pet Program Coordinator. As part of our goal to make the community more dog-friendly, we recently opened a new dog park. The park was designed to provide an enjoyable experience for both dogs and owners. There are big grassy areas where your dogs can run, jump, and play. We have separate spaces for small dogs and big dogs, to ensure safety. You'll also find lots of benches and areas for resting and staying cool. We hope you will have a wonderful time with your dogs in this newly opened park.

Regards, Lily Paxton, Pet Program Coordinator

The amount of effort, time, or decision making required by an action has a huge influence on habit formation. To a truly remarkable extent, we're more likely to do something if it's convenient, and less likely if it's not. Putting a wastebasket next to our front door made mail sorting slightly more convenient, and I stopped procrastinating with this chore. Many people report that they do a much better job of staying close to distant family members now that tools like group chats make it easy to stay in touch.

Getting into an actual routine of regular exercise is harder. In this sense, science really solves no problems at all. Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it. In fact, many of humanity's biggest problems are caused by lack of action, and not lack of knowledge.

We think we're being logical, objective, and rational — and therefore accurate in our analysis, judgment, and decisions. So we think that if other people are logical, objective, and rational, they will agree with us and see what we see. But the opposite is the case. Every human brain is different. Everyone's life experience is different. Everyone's desires and knowledge are different. You might think you're being realistic — that is, that your ideas match reality, but that's impossible. It's only your interpretation of reality, which will always be different from someone else's. When two nations play each other in the World Cup, the fans of each country criticize the referees for missing all the infractions that the other team commits. Without fail, each fan base believes that the referees are biased against their team.

People often ask me, "What surprises you most about habits?" One thing that continually astonishes me is the degree to which we're influenced by sheer convenience. The amount of effort, time, or decision making required by an action has a huge influence on habit formation. To a truly remarkable extent, we're more likely to do something if it's convenient, and less likely if it's not. For this reason, we should pay close attention to the convenience of any activity we want to make into a habit. Putting a wastebasket next to our front door made mail sorting slightly more convenient, and I stopped procrastinating with this chore. Many people report that they do a much better job of staying close to distant family members now that tools like group chats make it easy to stay in touch.

annotations.html:
(1) The author is surprised by how much convenience affects habit formation. ( T / F )
(2) The effort required for an action has little impact on whether it becomes a habit. ( T / F )
(3) The author stopped procrastinating with mail sorting after making the task more convenient. ( T / F )
(4) According to the text, people should ignore convenience when trying to form new habits. ( T / F )
(5) Tools like group chats have made it more difficult for people to stay in touch with distant family members. ( T / F )

It is common sense that people's inner beliefs may drive their external behavior. If you're attracted to a certain person, you should be more likely to socialize with that person. If you favor a brand of toothpaste, you're more likely to buy it. Of course, our internal thoughts don't always predict our public behavior, but, overall, what we do obviously reflects what we think. But beliefs and behaviors are also related in a more remarkable way. It turns out that the arrow is as likely to point in the reverse direction. As social psychologist David Myers observes, "If social psychology has taught us anything during the last 25 years, it is that we are likely not only to think ourselves into a way of acting but also to act ourselves into a way of thinking."

annotations.html:
(1) According to the text, inner beliefs always predict external behavior. ( T / F )

Imagine following the spirit of a silence vow into daily life. Challenge yourself to spend an entire day saying only what you absolutely must say. It's been widely observed by behavioral psychology experts — and anyone who's ever been on a first date — that we too often tend to treat "conversation" as a game of waiting for our own turn to speak. We miss what's being said because we're mentally rehearsing our next utterance. What if you could eliminate the idea that the next available mini-silence is your next opening to express whatever is in your head? What if you were limited to, say, fifty spoken words tomorrow? I think you'd listen quite differently. You'd attend quite carefully to every word you heard. You'd be attuned to what you must respond to. You might discover that the less you say, the more you hear.

(4) The text suggests that speaking less might improve one's listening abilities. ( T / F )
(5) According to the text, people often miss what's being said because they're planning what to say next. ( T / F )

Science is concerned with accumulating and understanding observations of the physical world. That understanding alone solves no problems. Individual people have to act on that understanding for it to help solve problems. For instance, science has found that regular exercise can lower your risk of heart disease. Knowing this fact is interesting, but it will do nothing for your personal health unless you act on it and actually exercise. And that's the hard part. Reading an article about exercise is easy. Getting into an actual routine of regular exercise is harder. In this sense, science really solves no problems at all. Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it. In fact, many of humanity's biggest problems are caused by lack of action, and not lack of knowledge.

(1) Science itself directly solves humanity's problems without requiring human action. ( T / F )

(5) Science's primary purpose is gathering and comprehending observations of the physical world. ( T / F )

annotations.text: 다음의 내용과 일치하는 것을 고르시오.

People often ask me, "What surprises you most about habits?" One thing that continually astonishes me is the degree to which we're influenced by sheer convenience. The amount of effort, time, or decision making required by an action has a huge influence on habit formation. To a truly remarkable extent, we're more likely to do something if it's convenient, and less likely if it's not. For this reason, we should pay close attention to the convenience of any activity we want to make into a habit. Putting a wastebasket next to our front door made mail sorting slightly more convenient, and I stopped procrastinating with this chore. Many people report that they do a much better job of staying close to distant family members now that tools like group chats make it easy to stay in touch.

annotations.html:
① The text states that group chats have made it more difficult for people to maintain relationships with distant family members.
② The author believes that habit formation is primarily influenced by personal motivation rather than convenience.
③ The author is surprised by how little impact convenience has on people's daily habits.
④ According to the text, the author started to sort mail regularly after moving the front door closer to the wastebasket.
⑤ The author suggests that making an activity more convenient can help transform it into a habit.
annotations.text:
① The text states that group chats have made it more difficult for people to maintain relationships with distant family members.
② The author believes that habit formation is primarily influenced by personal motivation rather than convenience.
③ The author is surprised by how little impact convenience has on people's daily habits.
④ According to the text, the author started to sort mail regularly after moving the front door closer to the wastebasket.
⑤ The author suggests that making an activity more convenient can help transform it into a habit.

annotations.html: 다음의 내용과 일치하는 것을 고르시오.
annotations.text: 다음의 내용과 일치하는 것을 고르시오.

It is common sense that people's inner beliefs may drive their external behavior. If you're attracted to a certain person, you should be more likely to socialize with that person. If you favor a brand of toothpaste, you're more likely to buy it. Of course, our internal thoughts don't always predict our public behavior, but, overall, what we do obviously reflects what we think. But beliefs and behaviors are also related in a more remarkable way. It turns out that the arrow is as likely to point in the reverse direction. As social psychologist David Myers observes, "If social psychology has taught us anything during the last 25 years, it is that we are likely not only to think ourselves into a way of acting but also to act ourselves into a way of thinking."

annotations.html:
① According to social psychology, our actions can shape our thinking patterns.
② David Myers claims that our behaviors cannot influence our way of thinking.
③ The relationship between beliefs and behaviors is only one-directional.
④ Social psychologists have been studying the relationship between thoughts and actions for less than a decade.
⑤ Internal thoughts always predict our public behavior without exception.
annotations.text:
① According to social psychology, our actions can shape our thinking patterns.
② David Myers claims that our behaviors cannot influence our way of thinking.
③ The relationship between beliefs and behaviors is only one-directional.
④ Social psychologists have been studying the relationship between thoughts and actions for less than a decade.
⑤ Internal thoughts always predict our public behavior without exception.

annotations.text: 다음의 내용과 일치하는 것을 고르시오.

Imagine following the spirit of a silence vow into daily life. Challenge yourself to spend an entire day saying only what you absolutely must say. It's been widely observed by behavioral psychology experts — and anyone who's ever been on a first date — that we too often tend to treat "conversation" as a game of waiting for our own turn to speak. We miss what's being said because we're mentally rehearsing our next utterance. What if you could eliminate the idea that the next available mini-silence is your next opening to express whatever is in your head? What if you were limited to, say, fifty spoken words tomorrow? I think you'd listen quite differently. You'd attend quite carefully to every word you heard. You'd be attuned to what you must respond to. You might discover that the less you say, the more you hear.

annotations.html:
① The author suggests that speaking fewer than twenty words per day is the optimal practice.
② People often miss what others are saying because they are preparing their own response.
③ Behavioral psychology experts recommend a complete vow of silence for effective communication.
④ The main purpose of limiting speech is to improve one's vocabulary and language skills.
⑤ People on first dates tend to listen more attentively than in other social situations.
annotations.text:
① The author suggests that speaking fewer than twenty words per day is the optimal practice.
② People often miss what others are saying because they are preparing their own response.
③ Behavioral psychology experts recommend a complete vow of silence for effective communication.
④ The main purpose of limiting speech is to improve one's vocabulary and language skills.
⑤ People on first dates tend to listen more attentively than in other social situations.

Science is concerned with accumulating and understanding observations of the physical world. That understanding alone solves no problems. Individual people have to act on that understanding for it to help solve problems. For instance, science has found that regular exercise can lower your risk of heart disease. Knowing this fact is interesting, but it will do nothing for your personal health unless you act on it and actually exercise. And that's the hard part. Reading an article about exercise is easy. Getting into an actual routine of regular exercise is harder. In this sense, science really solves no problems at all. Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it. In fact, many of humanity's biggest problems are caused by lack of action, and not lack of knowledge.

annotations.html:
① Knowledge about exercise benefits needs to be applied through action to improve health.
② Scientific knowledge is less important than personal intuition when making health decisions.
③ Reading scientific articles about exercise is as difficult as maintaining an exercise routine.
④ Science itself is responsible for solving humanity's biggest problems.
⑤ Most of humanity's biggest problems stem from insufficient scientific understanding.
annotations.text:
① Knowledge about exercise benefits needs to be applied through action to improve health.
② Scientific knowledge is less important than personal intuition when making health decisions.
③ Reading scientific articles about exercise is as difficult as maintaining an exercise routine.
④ Science itself is responsible for solving humanity's biggest problems.
⑤ Most of humanity's biggest problems stem from insufficient scientific understanding.

annotations.html: 다음의 내용과 일치하는 것을 고르시오.
annotations.text: 다음의 내용과 일치하는 것을 고르시오.

We think we're being logical, objective, and rational — and therefore accurate in our analysis, judgment, and decisions. So we think that if other people are logical, objective, and rational, they will agree with us and see what we see. But the opposite is the case. Every human brain is different. Everyone's life experience is different. Everyone's desires and knowledge are different. You might think you're being realistic — that is, that your ideas match reality, but that's impossible. It's only your interpretation of reality, which will always be different from someone else's. When two nations play each other in the World Cup, the fans of each country criticize the referees for missing all the infractions that the other team commits. Without fail, each fan base believes that the referees are biased against their team.

annotations.html:
① Most people are aware that their perception of reality is subjective rather than objective.
② Each person has a unique interpretation of reality based on their individual experiences.
③ When watching World Cup matches, fans generally acknowledge the fairness of referees.
④ The text suggests that human brains function identically when processing information.
⑤ People who are logical and rational will always reach the same conclusions.
annotations.text:
① Most people are aware that their perception of reality is subjective rather than objective.
② Each person has a unique interpretation of reality based on their individual experiences.
③ When watching World Cup matches, fans generally acknowledge the fairness of referees.
④ The text suggests that human brains function identically when processing information.
⑤ People who are logical and rational will always reach the same conclusions.

Dear Dog Owners,
My name is Lily Paxton, and I'm the town's Pet Program Coordinator. As part of our goal to make the community more dog-friendly, we recently opened a new dog park. The park was designed to provide an enjoyable experience for both dogs and owners. There are big grassy areas where your dogs can run, jump, and play. We have separate spaces for small dogs and big dogs, to ensure safety. You'll also find lots of benches and areas for resting and staying cool. We hope you will have a wonderful time with your dogs in this newly opened park.

Regards, Lily Paxton, Pet Program Coordinator

Science is concerned with accumulating and understanding observations of the physical world. That understanding alone solves no problems. Individual people have to act on that understanding for it to help solve problems. For instance, science has found that regular exercise can lower your risk of heart disease. Knowing this fact is interesting, but it will do nothing for your personal health unless you act on it and actually exercise. And that's the hard part. Reading an article about exercise is easy. __________ is harder. In this sense, science really solves no problems at all. Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it. In fact, many of humanity's biggest problems are caused by lack of action, and not lack of knowledge.

It's only your interpretation of reality, which will always be different from someone else's. annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 우리의 행동이 우리의 생각과 신념에 영향을 미칠 수 있다는 개념을 나타낸다. 본문에서는 일반적으로 내면의 신념이 외적 행동을 이끈다는 상식적인 견해를 먼저 제시한 후, "화살표가 반대 방향을 가리킬 가능성이 있다"고 언급하며 행동이 생각에 영향을 미칠 수 있다는 역방향의 관계를 설명하고 있다. 사회심리학자 David Myers의 인용문은 이러한 양방향 관계를 명확히 보여주며, 우리가 생각을 통해 행동하는 방식을 형성할 뿐만 아니라 행동을 통해 생각하는 방식을 형성할 수 있음을 강조한다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 말을 적게 할수록 더 많이 듣게 된다는 의미로, 대화에서 자신의 발언을 최소화함으로써 진정한 경청 능력이 향상된다는 개념을 표현한다. 본문에서는 우리가 대화를 자신의 차례를 기다리는 게임처럼 여기며, 다음에 할 말을 준비하느라 상대방의 말을 놓치는 경향이 있다고 설명한다. 따라서 말을 제한하면 "You'd attend quite carefully to every word you heard"라고 언급된 것처럼 더 주의 깊게 듣게 되고, 이는 결국 진정한 경청 능력의 향상으로 이어진다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 과학적 지식 자체만으로는 문제를 해결할 수 없으며, 사람들이 그 지식을 실제로 행동으로 옮겨야만 문제가 해결된다는 의미이다. 본문에서는 규칙적인 운동이 심 장병 위험을 낮출 수 있다는 과학적 사실을 알고 있더라도, 실제로 운동을 하지 않으면 개인의 건강에 도움이 되지 않는다는 예시를 들고 있다. 또한 "Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it"라고 명시적으로 언급하며, 과학 이 제공하는 지식을 사람들이 활용할 때만 문제가 해결된다고 강조하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 일반적으로 사람들의 내면적 신념이 외적 행동을 이끈다는 상식적인 관계를 설명한 후, 더 주목할 만한 점은 그 관계가 역방향으로도 작용한다는 것을 강조하고 있다. 사회심리학자 David Myers의 말을 인용하여 "우리가 생각을 통해 행동하는 방식을 형성할 뿐만 아니라, 행동을 통해 생각하는 방식도 형성한다"는 양방향적 관계를 명확히 보여주고 있다. 따라서 신념과 행동이 서로 영향을 주고받는 쌍방향 관계를 의미하는 "Behavior and Belief: A Two-Way Street"가 글의 핵심 내용을 가장 적절하게 담고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 일상에서 침묵의 서약 정신을 따르며 꼭 필요한 말만 하는 도전을 제안하고 있다. 글쓴이는 대화를 자신의 차례를 기다리는 게임처럼 여기는 경향이 있어 상대방의 말을 놓치게 된다고 지적하며, 만약 하루에 말할 수 있는 단어 수가 제한된다면 듣는 방식이 달라질 것이라고 주장한다. "You might discover that the less you say, the more you hear"라는 글의 마지막 문장은 글의 핵심 메시지를 담고 있으며, 말을 적게 할수록 더 많이 듣게 된다는 의도적 침묵의 가치를 강조하고 있다.

annotations.html: 이 글은 과학이 물리적 세계에 대한 관찰을 축적하고 이해하는 것과 관련이 있지만, 그 이해만으로는 문제를 해결하지 못한다고 설명한다. "That understanding alone solves no problems"와 "science really solves no problems at all"이라는 표현을 통해 과학적 지식이 행동으로 옮겨지지 않는다면 무용하다는 점을 강조한다. 글의 핵심은 "Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it"이며, 인류의 많은 문제가 지식의 부족이 아닌 행동의 부족에서 비롯된다는 점을 지적하고 있으므로 과학의 한계가 지식과 행동 사이의 간극에 있다는 제목이 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 이 글은 사람들이 자신의 생각이 논리적이고 객관적이며 합리적이라고 믿지만, 실제로는 모든 사람의 뇌가 다르고 삶의 경험과 욕구, 지식이 다르기 때문에 현실에 대한 해석이 다를 수밖에 없다는 점을 설명하고 있다. 글에서는 "You might think you're being realistic - that is, that your ideas match reality, but that's impossible. It's only your interpretation of reality, which will always be different from someone else's"라고 명시하며 객관성에 대한 착각을 지적한다. 월드컵 경기에서 각 팀의 팬들이 심판이 자기 팀에 불리하게 편향되어 있다고 믿는 예시는 이러한 주관적 현실 인식의 차이를 잘 보여주는 사례이다.

annotations.html: 이 글은 습관 형성에 있어 편리함이 미치는 영향력에 대해 설명하고 있다. 글쓴이는 사람들이 편리하면 어떤 행동을 할 가능성이 높고, 불편하면 그 가능성이 낮아진다고 강조한다. 이러한 맥락에서 습관으로 만들고 싶은 활동의 '편리함에 세심한 주의를 기울여야' 한다는 것이 글의 핵심 메시지이다. 쓰레기통을 현관 옆에 두어 우편물 정리를 더 편리하게 만든 예시와 그룹 채팅과 같은 도구가 멀리 있는 가족과의 연락을 쉽게 만든다는 후속 내용도 이를 뒷받침한다.

annotations.html: 이 글은 내적 신념이 외적 행동을 이끈다는 일반적인 생각에서 시작하여, 그 관계가 역방향으로도 작용할 수 있다는 점을 설명하고 있다. 빈칸 뒤에 이어지는 "in the reverse direction"과 David Myers의 인용문에서 "act ourselves into a way of thinking"이라는 표현은 행동이 사고방식에 영향을 미칠 수 있음을 강조한다. 따라서 빈칸에는 이러한 양방향 관계를 화살표에 비유한 "the arrow is as likely to point"가 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 침묵의 서약 정신을 일상생활에 적용하는 것에 관한 내용으로, 대화 중에 상대방의 말을 경청하기보다 자신의 차례를 기다리며 다음 발언을 준비하는 경향이 있다고 지적한다. 빈칸 이후의 내용에서 "다음 발언 기회에 머릿속에 있는 것을 표현하는 것"이라는 맥락이 이어지고, 말을 적게 할수록 더 많이 듣게 된다는 결론으로 연결된다. 따라서 "다음 미니 침묵이 자신의 발언 기회라는 생각"이 빈칸에 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 과학이 물리적 세계에 대한 관찰을 축적하고 이해하는 것에 관련되어 있지만, 그 이해만으로는 문제가 해결되지 않는다는 점을 강조한다. 글의 핵심 주장은 과학적 지식이 실제 행동으로 옮겨질 때만 문제가 해결된다는 것이다. 규칙적인 운동이 심장병 위험을 낮춘다는 과학적 사실을 아는 것만으로는 충분하지 않고, 실제로 운동을 해야만 개인의 건강에 도움이 된다는 예시를 통해 이를 뒷받침한다. 따라서 "과학은 실제로 문제를 전혀 해결하지 않는다"는 표현이 빈칸에 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 우리가 논리적이고 객관적이며 합리적이라고 생각하지만, 실제로는 모든 사람의 뇌와 경험, 욕구, 지식이 다르기 때문에 현실에 대한 인식도 다를 수밖에 없다는 내용이다. 빈칸 앞에서 '당신의 생각이 현실과 일치한다고 생각할 수 있지만, 그것은 불가능하다'라고 했으며, 빈칸 뒤에서는 '항상 다른 사람의 것과 다를 것'이라고 했다. 또한 월드컵 경기 예시를 통해 같은 상황을 보더라도 각 팬들이 심판의 판정을 다르게 해석한다는 점을 강조하고 있다. 따라서 빈칸에는 '현실에 대한 당신의 해석'이 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글의 전체 흐름은 사람들이 자신의 판단이 객관적이라고 생각하지만 실제로는 각자의 뇌, 경험, 지식이 달라 현실에 대한 해석이 다르다는 것이다. 월드컵 경기에서 각 팀의 팬들이 심판이 자기 팀에 불리하게 판정한다고 믿는 예시는 이러한 주관적 해석의 사례로 제시되었다. 그러나 ②번 문장은 축구 경기에서 심판이 내리는 판정의 수와 그 주관성에 대한 통계적 정보로, 글의 핵심 주제인 '현실 인식의 주관성'과는 직접적인 관련이 없다.

(2) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, 행동에 필요한 노력은 습관 형성에 큰 영향을 미친다. "The amount of effort,

(3) 해설: 저자는 현관문 옆에 쓰레기통을 두어 우편물 정리를 더 편리하게 만든 후 이 일을 미루지 않게 되었다. 텍스트에서 "Putting a wastebasket next to our front door made mail sorting slightly more convenient, and I stopped procrastinating with this chore."라고 설명되어 있다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트는 새로운 습관을 형성하려 할 때 편리함에 주의를 기울여야 한다고 조언한다. "For this
reason, we should pay close attention to the convenience of any activity we want to make into a habit."라고 언급되어 있다.
(5) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, 그룹 채팅과 같은 도구들은 사람들이 멀리 떨어진 가족들과 더 쉽게 연락을 유지할 수 있게 해주었다. "Many people report that they do a much better job of staying close to distant family members now that tools like group chats make it easy to stay in touch."라고 언급되어 있다.
